Artificial limits almost ruin an otherwise great game. Coincidentally, the DLCs relax these issues (i.e. inventory size, vendor discounts, difficulty quite high at start of game, etc.)I was planning on buying the DLC because I like the game a lot. But I'm not OK with game balancing fixes locked behind a paywall (which in practice change 1 number). Bandai Namco should stick to cosmetic DLC and other extra content which I'll gladly buy without remorse.
One of the best sniper shooters on the market. Highly recommend if you're into stealth, sniping or even general first person shooters.

As much as I hated coding in Assembly at university, I love the similar style of working here. The limited registry space and basic syntax really make each puzzle a very interesting challenge. You've got to make the solution work within that limited space and that really makes it so rewarding when you do get it. Plus, it's just super satisfying to see your little bots do their thing and execute your instructions. Highly recommend to any coder who's a fan of puzzles!

Surprisingly addictive and fun game. The graphics are really simple, but the gameplay is rock solid. Doesn't need a complicated storyline or fancy cutscenes. Just good old, arcade style gameplay. And it costs less than a burger at a fast-food joint. Love it!

A great idle game where you program your own tools and abilities to engage in the idling. If you're familiar with Javascript or any programming language, you'll have a lot of fun optimizing your scripts and improving your technique as you go through the game. Bitburner also continues to offer more challenges and new tidbits of information to keep you interested and engaged throughout. Although I will point out that once you reach a certain threshold of automation and progress, the game seems to shift a lot more to the side of "just wait a long time" versus "optimize everything." I personally enjoyed the latter part a lot, thinking up strategies for optimally leeching off of the various servers and improving your scripts, making new tools to give you more information, etc... However after playing for a decent bit, I have most of everything automated and scripted and even the "new game plus" modes, as it were, just seem to grind everything to a halt even more. In conclusion, I definitely recommend it, and it's a ton of fun when you start out. However once you get to a certain point, the game just grinds down and stops giving that fun optimization feel that you get when starting out. But it's free, and I definitely put plenty of hours into it that I really enjoyed, so have fun with it!!

The game is great, don't read more about it, just go and play. The less you know about it, the better your experience will be.---If you want some more insight; if you like card games, deck builders or just are even remotely into anything strategic like that, go play this. It's an experience like no other.

Revisitor is a really good combination between puzzle solving and quick platforming. Some levels will have you breaking your brain about which combinations of switches use or which order of doors to open. While other levels require more precision platforming, timing your jumps correctly or being swift with your movement.Speaking of movement; the way you move in the game feels very smooth. Everything from using your abilities to simply moving around and interacting with the world goes without a hitch. Especially when you need to be precise, this really makes the experience pop and truly lets the game come alive.The combination of those factors make for a very entertaining experience. But the game also delivers plenty when it comes to the soundtrack, which is great to play along to. Each level has a unique soundtrack (at least so far) and they're all perfectly suited to the environment the game takes place in. And there's plenty of levels to keep you entertained. There's multiple hidden levels that you have to unlock by retrieving secrets and if that's not enough, you can even start speed running the game and trying to beat your past time on each level!The entire game just oozes polish, from the visuals, to the sound design, to the amount of content you get. I would've gladly paid $10 for this, but as it stands, the developer is mental and decided to release this for free. There is plenty of games that are going for over $10 right now with less content and less polish than you get with Revisitor. I highly recommend you give it a try if you're even a little into puzzling and/or platforming and guarantee you'll have a great time with it!
I adore these kinds of abstract games and this is the perfect teaser for the main game. I'm definitely going to be picking it up. There's more exploring to be done!!

Really unique turn-based, tactics game with roguelite elements. The world building is very interesting and the dynamics within the gameplay result in you having to make some difficult choices. Highly recommend if you're into these sorts of games.

The tool itself is interesting and can definitely create some nice scenery, however I simply can't recommend it because of one reason; the User Interface and everything connected to it. Most of the UI is literally a box with a color and a symbol, the hint text in the loading screen is often barely readable because it's white on a light background, most buttons are never explained and even if they have a tooltip it doesn't explain what it does half the time. It even starts before the game is loaded, when you select your resolution, graphical settings and language, which looks like an interface purely meant during testing for the developer. To create new stuff you've gotta navigate multiple tiered lists that then often have more objects hidden inside them, which you have to just stumble across. When editing properties there are numerous sliders that again are hidden behind layers of menu's, without proper explanations, tutorials or even tooltips.The list goes on and on. If the developer would either hire a designer or put some actual effort into the UI it might be a really fun and relaxing experience. However as it stands, it's like playing Dark Souls using 2 bananas and an orange peel for controllers. You can see there's some real fun to be had, but you're just constantly struggling with the way to interact with all that fun.

Super unique and amazingly fun game. It's a great combination between the satisfaction of destructible environments and puzzling out the optimal approach in each level. There are no wrong answers, only better scores.

This version of Kingdom is the third in the series and another iteration of the same game: which I love! So it's hard not to enjoy more of the same but with some changes and extras thrown in. Not certain it's worth it at full price if you've played another in the series but definitely worthwhile on sale if you enjoy this style of gameplay. The soundtrack is fantastic.

It's a good sandbox. It's not a good game.So if you like Just Cause because it's an open world full of unique mechanics, you'll no doubt find something to like here. The controls can be a bit janky and the graphics not up to modern day scrutiny but there's definitely fun to be had.If you want a good game with interesting and varied objectives, look elsewhere because the entire mission set from beginning to end is defending a confined area for time, or going through hoops. In isolation these can be fun but when the entire game is one or the other, it gets very dull, very quick.Edit: after all the updates and DLC it's much the same experience just with a few added gadgets and gimmicks

17/02/18 Not as good as the 1st game. So many things are different. NPCs are no longer predictable. Deer refuse top run away from you. Builders don't stay inside compound at night. I should not have to amass an army with only one NPC camp to recruit from! While the first game was a fun exploration and discovery, this one is just infuriating beyond belief. I find myself screaming at the srceen at the idiotic things I am witnessing that never happened in the first game and I'm not sure if being brutally unfair is an adequote substitute for difficulty. Even the beautiful soundtrack is not enough to calm me. This is not a worthy sequel. Disappointing.EDIT 25/04/19: after having gone back to the game again and finally finding some success maybe I was a little harsh, or maybe the game has been tweaked. Either way it seems to play a lot better now that I understand the newer mechanics of this version. Worth a shot if you see it on sale, especially if you liked the first game

A beautiful game and experience. The minimial approach to storyline combined with the visuals and gameplay work very well together. The music just elevates an already great game to another level. Wonderful. If only there was more.
A pure classic worthy of it's place in the Gaming Hall of Fame 10/10

Just cause 3 is different to JC2. If you take that on board you'll have more fun!I really like JC3 although it does have flaws. The wingsuit is amazing, exploring the map is an enjoyable experience and experimenting with the mechics is endlessly hilarious. There's plenty of things to do and I found the game easily ate up 50+ hrs while liberating all the settlements, completing the storyline and getting all the collectables.Once you've done all that you're kinda left to your own devices. Unless you actively enjoy experimenting with the mechanics of the game, or happen to enjoy stunts there's not an awful lot left to do. You can reinstate individual locations and liberate them again but it's a little bit of an empty process with no goal. As a single player open world game this is a huge mistake not to add some kind of value to the game after it has been completed (DLC is on it's way but we don't have any idea of what content it will provide yet)This is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to flaws. There's design decisions that leave me baffled: no FOV slider or choice of camera angles (I think they ran out of control pad buttons to use lol), assigning boost to different buttons depending on the type of vehicle you're in. The weird delay you get between stunt jumping on a vehicle and being able to grapple. The main island being virtually empty. The dumb AI. The crashing. The list goes on and on. The lack of keybindings. Jeez I could talk about the flaws for a LONG time as there are so many and they really do effect the expereince negatively.Having said all that, I'm a huge fan of the Just CAuse franchise and the possibilities the game yields. As such I'm ok with overlooking the flaws. I spend a lot of my time stunting or creating silly experiments in JC3 and it's easily been worth the money paid. Will you enjoy it as much? I'm not sure... I suppose it depends how you play games. If you follow the missions and complete the story before moving on you may miss a lot about what makes JC3 so unique and enjoyable. However if you're more creative with your gameplay then you'll likely get a lot more from the experience.Either way I'm looking to the future now as the DLC shall be here soon (hopefully with more map content) and the JC2MP Team are working on a multiplayer mod for Just Cause 3.... which will change EVERYTHING!

Just Cause 2 Multiplayer is revolutionary. No other game offers the same level of insane chaos this game can muster.From the moment it began as a mod after being backward engineered by Trix it was obvious to many that the potential was huge. During the beta tests Just Cause 2 Multiplayer gained a cult following and developed a keen audience eager to play and experiment with others in a massively diverse and interesting game world.Personally I have played Just Cause 2 Multiplayer in so many different ways it's astounding that it really is just one game. I've played with friends experimenting with the grapple and laughed my head off. I've arranged Destruction Derby that were so successful the developers made a gamemode out of it. I've participated in some of the biggest, most insane mass racing, skydiving and faction wars I've ever witnessed in a game. I've performed solo and combination stunts with friends while co-ordinating over voice chat. I've went on a kill spee with my trusty sniper rifle and noscpoe killed hundred of enemies (other players at the airport).It truely is an amazing game with almost no limitations: the biggest is probably your imagination.If you thought Just Cause 2 was good then you're gonna be blown away by the multiplayer with 100+ players on a server. It's something special.

The best in the series an underrated classic. The racing is fast and furious with spectacular crashes! The collision and damage engines are great for when it came out, hell, it's better than some games today! If you enjoy driving games with a lot of chaos and destruction then this is a game you have to try!

Hands down the best open world game I've ever played. There's also a 3rd party multiplayer mod in development www.jc-mp.com......I'm a huge fan of open world games, from the original GTA way back in the 90's right up to it's latest incarnation GTAIV. I've also enjoyed Shenmue, Dragon Quest, Bully, Fallout, Farcry, Spiderman, Burnout, Arkham City..... any genre, any platform- it's easily my favourite type of gameworld. But the mechanics make a game and Just Cause 2 has the most fun mechanics I've ever played with. The possibilities are only limited to your imagination....... and skill.......Wanna steal a fighterjet? Cool, Rico can do that. Wanna fly that plane toward a bridge, jump on top and surf the jet under the bridge? Fine, Rico can do that. Wanna jump from a building flying through death defying gaps and before hitting the ground, release your parachute and walk away unharmed? Rico can do that one too. Really, once you get the hang of the controls the game comes to life in a way I've experienced in no other.......That would be my recommendation over if it wasn't for one final thing. Just Cause 2 Multiplayer. It's exactly what it sounds like and so much more. This is a mod that allows over 2000 players to join a single server, playing together on the same map. Nobody should allow themselves to ignore the fact that this really is a landmark in gaming. Never has a game of action orientated 3rd person shooting/jumping/driving been played on this scale. The closest would be something like GTAIV multiplayer on PC with up to 32 players. 2000+ Players is a whole new league above and beyond what I ever thought possible. You should try it > www.jc-mp.com
300+ hours on record means it must be pretty good.
